awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Atomic Force Microscope for interdisciplinary undergraduate research at Georgia Gwinnett College
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) Program, Professor Neelam Khan from Georgia Gwinnett College (GGC) and colleague Simon Mwongela have acquired an atomic force microscope (AFM). In an AFM a laser beam is directed to a surface area by means of a cantilever (a tip anchored at only one end). As the cantilever is displaced by interacting with the surface a reflection of the laser beam is displayed on a detector (photodiode). In this way an image of the surface can be created with the aid of an electronic system. In general, an AFM has three major abilities: force measurement, imaging and manipulation. This microscopy instrument is used to investigate the surface of materials and enable researchers to obtain nanoscale-level details of surface structure, morphology and interaction forces for a wide range of systems. The technique provides images which enable characterization of surfaces on various materials such as polymers, biological materials and aerosols. Information is obtained on magnetic, electronic and mechanical properties which can lead to improvement in desirable properties for materials such as semiconductors, vertebrate visual pigments and water filtration membranes. The instrumentation is used in research projects undertaken by undergraduates providing invaluable real-world, hands-on training for future careers in higher education or industry.  

The instrumentation will be used in research at Georgia Gwinnett College especially in areas such as (a) chracterizing semiconductors of groups II-V; (b) characterizing the packing of rhodopsin, a visual pigment, at membrane surfaces; (c) studying conductive polymer film morphology as a function of biomolecular oxidant; (d) analyzing natural and synthetic neuromelanin; (e) analyzing single-particles of local tropospheric aerosols; and (f) analyzing interactions between pollutants and membranes.

por.por_cntn:
With this award from Major Research Instrumentation program, GGC acquired an Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) for interdisciplinary research at Georgia Gwinnett College (GGC). AFM is a high resolution imaging tool that provides three dimensional information at nanoscale. It uses a sharp probe attached to a cantilever to scan across the sample surface. Probe-sample interactions cause the cantilever to deflect towards and away from the surface. Any changes in laser beam that is reflected from the surface of cantilever are tracked by photosensitive photodetector (PSPD). An electronic feedback loop maintains constant deflection and is used to acquire surface topography, interaction forces, electrical, and magnetic data.

Major Research Accomplishments

In Dr. Khan's research, undergraduate students worked in collaboration with Kansas State University researchers. The first project studied the effect of temperature on surface morphology and quality of scandium nitride (ScN) crystals. AFM revealed that the surface roughness decreased from 83 nm to 18 nm as the growth temperature was increased. The second project studied the effect of oxidation on hBN single crystals in ambient air as functions of temperature and time. The thermal oxidation of hBN crystals resulted in surface pits as was revealed by AFM. Pit depth increased linearly with temperature and oxidation times.

In Dr. Zimmermann's research, undergraduate student researchers conducted single particle analysis of marine aerosols collected from Skidaway Institute of Oceanography (Savannah, GA).  Students characterized marine aerosols collected at several different size fractions by obtaining height and phase images using soft-tapping AFM mode.  Preliminary results show that different sizes of marine aerosols display different mixing states (external versus internal) and core-shell morphologies were observed.

In Dr. Lee's research, undergraduate student researchers conducted studies on the interactions of water filtration membranes and aquatic foulants. Based on the deflection errors obtained using the AFM, there were variations in the interaction forces for different membrane materials and feed water compositions, and significant adverse effects of divalent ions on the fouling of membranes were observed.

In Dr. Morris's research, undergraduate students worked on two projects; 1) The study of the morphology of films of the conductive polymer PEDOT:PSS as a function of catalyst for polymer synthesis. Using AFM, students confirmed that film morphology did not differ between two polymers of different conductivities. 2) The study of the efficiency of mixed metal oxides as photocatalysts for splitting water. The plan is to quantify the efficiency, and investigate the materials through AFM as a function of annealing conditions.

In Dr. Haining's research, undergraduate students worked on studying the magnetic properties of neuromelanin (NM). Synthetic NM samples were allowed to polymerize on mica discs for varied time frames under altered buffer conditions. Samples were then rinsed with iron solution, dried and analyzed under AFM and MFM. NM samples appear to exhibit some of the expected magnetic properties. This has increased the understanding of this little-studied biological system.

Dr. Guo, intended to use AFM to monitor the height of the rhodopsin samples with different lipid compositions, and therefore determine the packing characteristics of rhodopsin at the membrane surface. During the reported period, the final yield of purification was not good enough to provide a sufficient amount of sample to be tested on AFM. She later on switched to another project which is to utilize AFM to determine the packing of BslA (a bacterial biofilm protein) at the glass/air surface. She plans to obtain the samples from her collaborator at Yale University, and work on them to compare the spectroscopic measurements with those from AFM.

Broader Impacts 

Acquisition of the AFM provided a significant increase in the level of research infrastructure at Georgia Gwinnett College. It provided more hands-on research opportunities to faculty and undergraduate students in disciplines of physics, biology, biochemistry, chemistry and environmental sciences. It provided opportunities for GGC undergraduate students and faculty to collaborate externally, and to present and publish data. A diverse group of undergraduates were involved in the research with the AFM. Demographic details of students and faculty who have worked on projects involving AFM are given below.

 

Male Students; 3 White and 1 African American

Female Students; 3 Asian, 2 White, 2 African American, and 1 Hispanic

Male Faculty; 3 White, and 2 Asian, and 1 African American

Female Faculty; 2 White and 2 Asian

 

Undergraduate research students and their faculty advisors successfully employed AFM to collect, analyze and present data at intramural and extramural venues. There were a total of 11 poster and oral presentation at internal venues, and two were at external venues.  Moreover, research work led to two peer-reviewed journal publications.
